p.text: Unless a contrary intention is expressed in the arbitration agreement, the award made by the arbitrator or umpire shall, subject to this Act, be final and binding on the parties to the agreement.
[s 28 am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
Legislation cited in [275,225.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 28.

A clause in an agreement providing only that decisions on questions of fact were to be final and binding manifests a “contrary intention” within the meaning of s 28 . Accordingly, an arbitrator's decision which entailed conclusions of law as to the binding nature of the agreement did not operate as an estoppel per rem judicatam: Penrith District Rugby League Football Club Ltd v Fittler (NSWSC, Santow J, No 4562/95, 30 January 1996, unreported, BC9600163) .
Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the parties to the arbitration agreement, the arbitrator or umpire shall—
make the award in writing;
sign the award; and
include in the award a statement of the reasons for making the award.
[subs (1) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]

Where an arbitrator or umpire makes an award otherwise than in writing, the arbitrator or umpire shall, upon request by a party within 7 days after the making of the award, give to the party a statement in writing signed by the arbitrator or umpire of the date, the terms of the award and the reasons for making the award.
Where an award made under an arbitration agreement contains—
a clerical mistake;
an error arising from an accidental slip or omission;
a material miscalculation of figures or a material mistake in the description of any person, thing or matter referred to in the award; or
a defect of form,
the arbitrator or umpire may correct the award or the Court, on the application of a party to the agreement, may make an order correcting the award.

The power of correction contained in the section does not permit an arbitrator to alter the name of a party where the issue of identity is substantially disputed and was not dealt with in the arbitration proceedings: Woodbud Pty Ltd v Warea Pty Ltd (1995) 125 FLR 346; BC9504818 : contrast Falck v Sernak Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 17 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,240] s 31 Interest up to making of award

leg:heading.title: Interest up to making of award

p.text: Unless a contrary intention is expressed in the arbitration agreement, but subject to subsection (4) , where the arbitrator or umpire determines to make an award for the payment of money (whether on a claim for a liquidated or an unliquidated amount), the arbitrator or umpire shall have power to include in the sum for which the award is made interest at such rate as the arbitrator or umpire may direct (being a rate not exceeding the rate at which interest is payable on a judgment debt of the Supreme Court) on the whole or any part of the money for the whole or any part of the period between the date on which the cause of action arose and the date on which the award is made.
[subs (1) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
Unless a contrary intention is expressed in the arbitration agreement, but subject to subsection (4) , where—
arbitration proceedings have been commenced for the recovery of a debt or liquidated damages; and
payment of the whole or a part of the debt or damages is made during the currency of the proceedings and prior to or without an award being made in respect of the debt or damages,

the arbitrator or umpire may order that interest be paid at such rate as the arbitrator or umpire may direct (being a rate not exceeding the rate at which interest is payable on a judgment debt of the Supreme Court) on the whole or any part of the money paid for the whole or any part of the period between the date when the cause of action arose and the date of the payment.
[subs (2) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
Without limiting subsection (2) , arbitration proceedings shall, for the purposes of that subsection, be deemed to have been commenced if—
a dispute to which the relevant arbitration agreement applies has arisen; and
a party to the agreement—

has served on another party to the agreement a notice requiring that other party to appoint an arbitrator or to join or concur in or approve of the appointment of an arbitrator in relation to the dispute;
has served on another party to the agreement a notice requiring the other party to refer, or to concur in the reference of, the dispute to arbitration; or

has taken any other step contemplated by the agreement or the law in force at the time the dispute arose, with a view to referring the dispute to arbitration or appointing, or securing the appointment of, an arbitrator in relation to the dispute.
This section does not—
authorise the awarding of interest upon interest;
apply in relation to any amount upon which interest is payable as of right whether by virtue of an agreement or otherwise; or
affect the damages recoverable for the dishonour of a bill of exchange.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,245] s 32 Interest on debt under award

p.text: Unless a contrary intention is expressed in the arbitration agreement, where the arbitrator or umpire makes an award for the payment of money, the arbitrator or umpire shall have power to direct that interest at the same rate as that at which interest is payable on a judgment debt of the Supreme Court shall be payable on and from the date of the making of the award or such later date as the arbitrator or umpire may specify on so much of the money as is from time to time unpaid and any interest that so accrues shall be deemed to form part of the award.
[subs (1) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
If judgment is entered by the Court in terms of an award, interest shall cease to accrue in pursuance of a direction under this section on the date of the entry of the judgment.
[subs (2) insrt Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]

An award made under an arbitration agreement may, by leave of the Court, be enforced in the same manner as a judgment or order of the Court to the same effect, and where leave is so given, judgment may be entered in terms of the award.
[subs (2) rep Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
[s 33 am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
Legislation cited in [275,250.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 33.

This section provides a summary procedure for enforcement in lieu of the conventional action on the award: Brali v Hyundai Corp (1988) 15 NSWLR 734; 84 ALR 176 . Leave may be given to enforce part only of an award (whether that need arises because the award has been performed in part or because the award contains a bad but severable provision): ACN 006 797 413 Pty Ltd (formerly called Palace Entertainment Corp Pty Ltd) v International Movie Group Canada Inc [1997] 2 VR 31 . Leave may also be given under s 33 to enforce an interim award in favour of one party in circumstances where the other party has an, as yet, unresolved counter claim: Commonwealth v Cockatoo Dockyards Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Mahoney P and Priestley JA, CA 40319/96, 15 August 1996, unreported, BC9603601) .
Legislation cited in [275,250.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 29(1)(c), s 33.

A party seeking to enforce an award pursuant to s 33 must at least prove (i) the submission to arbitration (so that the court may be satisfied that the award was made pursuant to and within the terms of that submission); (ii) that the arbitrator has given reasons for making the award in conformity with s 29(1)(c) ; and (iii) that the arbitrator was duly appointed: Rebenta Pty Ltd v Oceanview Apartments Pty Ltd (1997) 14 BCL 232 . The scope of a submission to arbitration may be expanded by an implied ad hoc agreement in the course of the arbitration: Rebenta Pty Ltd v Oceanview Apartments Pty Ltd , above; Costain Australia Ltd v Australian Airlines Ltd (VSC, Southwell J, 6 June 1988, unreported, BC8800695) ; Mark Blake Builders Pty Ltd v Davies (NSWSC, Giles J, 14 November 1994, unreported) .

Unless a contrary intention is expressed in the arbitration agreement, the costs of the arbitration (including the fees and expenses of the arbitrator or umpire) shall be in the discretion of the arbitrator or umpire, who may—
direct to and by whom and in what manner the whole or any part of those costs shall be paid;
settle the amount (or any part of the amount) of costs to be so paid, or arrange for the assessment of those costs (or any part of them), and
award costs to be assessed or settled as between party and party or as between legal practitioner and client.
[subs (1) am Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004 ; Act No 46 of 2005 s 5 and Sch 11, effective 1 October 2005]

Any costs of the arbitration (other than the fees or expenses of the arbitrator or umpire) that are directed to be paid by an award are to be assessed (except to the extent that they have been settled by the arbitrator or umpire).
[subs (2) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2 ; Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004 ]
A provision in an arbitration agreement (being an arbitration agreement that provides for the reference of future disputes to arbitration) is void if:
it is to the effect that a particular party, or the parties, to the agreement shall in any event pay their own costs of the arbitration or any part of those costs; or

except in so far as it relates to a right of indemnity or a right of subrogation — it is to the effect that a particular party to the agreement shall in any event pay the costs of any other party or any part of those costs.
[subs (3) subst Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]

If no provision is made by an award with respect to the costs of the arbitration, a party to the arbitration agreement may, within 14 days of the publication of the award, apply to the arbitrator or umpire for directions as to the payment of those costs, and thereupon the arbitrator or umpire shall, after hearing any party who wishes to be heard, amend the award by adding to it such directions as the arbitrator or umpire may think proper with respect to the payment of the costs of the arbitration.

Where a sum of money has been paid into the Court in accordance with rules of court in satisfaction of a claim to which an arbitration agreement applies, the arbitrator or umpire shall, in exercising the discretion as to costs conferred on the arbitrator or umpire by subsection (1) , take into account both the fact that money was paid into the Court and the amount of that payment.
[subs (5) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]

Where in accordance with rules of court an offer of compromise has been made in relation to a claim to which an arbitration agreement applies, the arbitrator or umpire shall, in exercising the discretion as to costs conferred on the arbitrator or umpire by subsection (1) , take into account both the fact that the offer was made and the terms of the offer.
[subs (6) subst Act 100 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 2]

An arbitrator or umpire shall, in exercising the discretion as to costs conferred on the arbitrator or umpire by subsection (1) , take into account any refusal or failure by a party to the arbitration agreement to comply with the provisions of section 37 .

Where there is an unusual departure from the normal rule that costs follow the event, an arbitrator should give reasons. If no reasons are given, the parties may put evidence before the court to enable the court to decide whether to intervene: G Hawkins Sons Pty Ltd v Cable Belt (Aust) Pty Ltd (1986) 3 BCL 217 .
Legislation cited in [275,255.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 34(1).

An arbitrator does not have jurisdiction under s 34(1) to award the costs of the reference on a full indemnity basis: South Australian Superannuation Fund Investment Trust v Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd (1996) 66 SASR 509 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,260] s 35 Assessment of arbitrator's or umpire's fees and expenses

leg:heading.title: Assessment of arbitrator's or umpire's fees and expenses

p.text: If an arbitrator or umpire refuses to deliver an award except on payment of the fees and expenses demanded by the arbitrator or umpire, the Court may, on application made by a party to the arbitration agreement, order that—
the arbitrator or umpire deliver the award to the applicant on such terms as to the payment of the fees and expenses of the arbitrator or umpire as the Court considers appropriate; and
the fees and expenses demanded by the arbitrator or umpire be assessed.
[subs (1) am Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004]

Notwithstanding that the amount of the fees or expenses of the arbitrator or umpire may be fixed by the award, those fees or expenses may, on the application of a party to the arbitration agreement or of the arbitrator or umpire, be assessed.
[subs (2) am Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004]
The arbitrator or umpire and any party to the arbitration agreement shall be entitled to make written submissions to the costs assessor in respect of any assessment required by this section.
[subs (3) am Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004]

Where the fees and expenses of an arbitrator or umpire are assessed, the arbitrator or umpire shall be entitled to be paid by way of fees and expenses only such sum as may be found fair and reasonable on assessment.
[subs (4) am Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,265] s 35A Application of Division 11 of Part 3.2 of Legal Profession Act 2004

leg:heading.title: Application of Division 11 of Part 3.2 of Legal Profession Act 2004

p.text: For the purposes of sections 34 and 35, Division 11 of Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 applies with any necessary modifications.
[s 35A insrt Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004 ; am Act No 46 of 2005 s 5 and Sch 11, effective 1 October 2005]

Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the parties to the arbitration agreement, where an arbitration is commenced but for any reason the arbitration fails, the Court may, on the application of a party to the arbitration agreement or the arbitrator or umpire, make such orders in relation to the costs of the arbitration as it thinks just.
For the purposes of this section, where—
a final award is not made by the arbitrator or umpire before the arbitration terminates; or
an award made is wholly set aside by the Court,
an arbitration shall be deemed to have failed.

The parties to an arbitration agreement shall at all times do all things which the arbitrator or umpire requires to enable a just award to be made and no party shall wilfully do or cause to be done any act to delay or prevent an award being made.
